##  {#ibi-why data-menu-title="Index Based Insurance"}

[Why Index Insurance?]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- **Fast payouts and cheap administration**

    - Money in policyholders accounts in as little as 3 days
    
<br>
    
- **Immune to fisher choices**

    - Fishers choosing to fish less will not lead to fund insolvency
    
    - Fishers cannot control sea surface temperature
    
<br>
    
- **Avoids quantifying individual loss**

    - Very difficult to indemnify whether a fisher lost income due to weather or their own luck
    
    
##  {#moral data-menu-title="Moral Hazards"}

[Index Insurance possesses moral hazards]{.slide-title}

<hr>    

:::{.callout-note icon=false}
## Moral Hazard Definition

Decisions by insured agents that they would not otherwise take if they were uninsured [@Wu2020]
:::

:::{.center-text}
**Theory from agriculture**
:::

- Insurance incentivizes farmers to change inputs use depending on the marginal risk effects of the inputs [@Mahul2001;@Ramaswami1993;@Babcock1996;@horowitz1993]

    - Insurance lowers input use of risk decreasing inputs
    
    - Insurance raises input use of risk increasing inputs
    
- Behavior change leads to environmental consequences [@Mishra2005;@Claassen2017]

- Rainfall insurance in common-pool pastures leads to overstocking and long term degradation of pasture commons [@Bulte2021;@muller2011]

##  {#results data-menu-title="Results Summary"}

[Results Summary]{.slide-title}

<hr>

**Result 1:** Index insurance will always increase harvest with standard fishing models

<br>

**Result 2:** The design of the contract matters. Contracts on extraction risks could increase or decrease, contracts on stock risks will always increase

<br>

**Result 3:** Incentives that increase harvest lead to larger absolute changes than decreases in harvest

    - Norwegian fisheries would increase harvest by 20% as oppossed to 2% decreases

##  {#mod data-menu-title="Model"}

[Standard Stochastic Fishery Model]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Stock abundance is the primary stochastic variable for fishers in a single period


$$
y=\tilde{B}f(x)
$$ {#eq-trad}

$\tilde{B}$ stochastic stock abundance

$f(x)$ concave technology function

::: {.fragment}
$$
y=\hat{B}f(x)+\theta f(x)
$$ {#eq-trad2}

$\hat{B}$ expected stock abundance

$\theta$ shock to stock abundance with $\mathbb{E}[\theta]=0$ and known variance $\sigma^2_\theta$

<br>

:::{.center-text}
$\theta$ will be called stock risk.
:::
:::


##  {#result1 data-menu-title="Result 1"}

[Result 1]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Under standard assumptions, fishers are price takers, incur convex costs, and are risk averse over profits.


Index Insurance will raise risk increasing inputs $\frac{\partial V(y)}{\partial x}>0$ [@Mahul2001]

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{V(y)}{\partial x} &= \sigma^2_\theta\frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x}>0 &\text{by concavity of $f(x)$}
\end{aligned}
$$

<br>

[**Result 1:** Index insurance will increase fishing effort if we apply traditional fishery models one-to-one]{.body-text-m}

:::{.callout-note icon=false}

## Intuition for Result 1 

Insurance protects against risk. The added risk of additional inputs is protected by insurance encouraging fishers to fish more
:::

::: fragment
***However, fishers are exposed to other risks and are quite adaptive to mitigating risk exposure***
:::

##  {#flex data-menu-title="Flexible"}

[Flexible Stochastic Production Function]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Other shocks may not influence quantity of biomass, but ability of fishers to harvest

![](presentations/img/tuna.jpg){.absolute top=165 left=40 width="100" height="75"}


$$
y=\hat{B}f(x)+\theta f(x)+\omega h(x)
$$ {#eq-jpfish}


:::: columns

::: column
$h(x)$ risk effect function

$\frac{\partial h(x)}{\partial x}\lessgtr0$

:::

::: column

$\omega$ extraction shock with $\mathbb{E}[\omega]=0$

:::

::::

Fishers can mitigate that risk through the risk effects function $h(x)$ with "extraction risk" $\omega$

<br>

**Now with two sources of risk and two margins to influence risk, unclear how insurance will change optimal input choice**

##  {#method data-menu-title="Solution Method"}

[We solve by solving the FOC of a maximization problem with insurance]{.slide-title}

<hr>

::: {style="font-size: 0.8em"}
$$
\begin{aligned}
U\equiv\max_{x}\mathbb{E}[U]=\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}&\left[\overbrace{ \int^{\bar \omega}_{-\infty}j_{\omega,\theta}(\omega,\theta)u(\pi(x,\hat{B},\theta,\omega)+(1-J(\bar \omega))\gamma)d\omega}^{\text{Insurance pays out on bad $\omega$}} \right.\\
&\left.+\underbrace{\int^{\infty}_{\bar{\omega}}j_{\omega,\theta}(\omega,\theta) u(\pi(x,\hat{B},
\theta,\omega)-J(\bar \omega)\gamma)d \omega}_{\text{Fisher pays premium in good state}}\right] d\theta
\end{aligned}
$$ {#eq-max}
:::

::::: columns
::: column
$u(\cdot)$ is concave utility

$\pi$ fisher profits from $y$

$j_{\omega,\theta}$ joint distribution of independent shocks
:::

::: column
$\gamma$ how much insurance pays out

$\bar\omega$ trigger value for a contract

$J(\bar\omega)\gamma$ is the premium
:::
:::::

##  {#ivt data-menu-title="IVT"}

[Apply IVT to analyze the direction of change in input use with insurance]{.slide-title}

<hr>

$$
\frac{\partial x^{*}}{\partial \gamma}=-\frac{\frac{\partial U}{\partial x \partial \gamma}}{\frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial x^{2}}}
$$ {#eq-ivt}

Focus on numerator because of the sufficent conditions of a maximization problem:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial U}{\partial x \partial \gamma}=\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}\left[ \int^{\bar \omega}_{-\infty}j_{\omega,\theta}(\omega,\theta)u''(\pi(x,\hat{B},\theta,\omega)+(1-J(\bar \omega))\gamma)\frac{\partial \pi}{\partial x}(x,\hat{B},\theta,\omega)(1-J(\bar \omega))d\omega\right.\\
+\left.\int^{\infty}_{\bar{\omega}}j_{\omega,\theta}(\omega,\theta) u''(\pi(x,\hat{B},\theta,\omega)-J(\bar \omega)\gamma)\frac{\partial \pi}{\partial x}(x,\hat{B},\theta,\omega)(-J(\bar \omega))d\omega\right] d\theta
\end{aligned}
$$ {#eq-xgam}

##  {#results2 data-menu-title="Results"}

[**Result 2:** Contracts specified on extraction shocks, $\omega$, could increase or decrease fisher harvest contingent on the risk effects ($\frac{\partial h(x)}{\partial x}$) of the input]{.body-text-l .blue-text}

[**Result 3:** Contracts specified on biological stock shocks, $\theta$, will always increase fisher harvest]{.body-text-l .blue-text}

<br>

***Intution: Insurance contracts protect risk along their specific margins. Fishers use that channel to reduce or increase inputs. Because of the implicit risk increasing nature of*** $f(x)$, $\theta$ contracts lead to harvest increases.
